I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  Alignment  with  Asian  Development  Bank  strategies.  The  transaction  technical 
assistance (TA) facility will provide capacity building to projects in Nepal financed by the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). The facility will support ADB’s country partnership strategy (CPS) for 
Nepal, 20132017, the forthcoming CPS for Nepal, 20202024, and ADB’s Strategy 2030.1 Given 
the growth and increasing complexity of ADB’s Nepal portfolio and the country’s transition from a 
central system to a three-tiered federal system of governance, ADB’s hands-on support for its 
Nepal projects is essential. Hence, a TA facility is proposed to provide systematic and demand-
driven capacity development for project implementation and evaluation, to support tripartite 
portfolio review meetings (TPRMs), and to provide targeted capacity development for ongoing 
and pipeline projects to improve effective project implementation. The TA facility is included in 
ADB’s country operations business plan for Nepal, 20192021, which is consistent with the 
extended CPS.2 ADB has discussed and reached an agreement with the Ministry of Finance 
(MOF) on the purpose, scope, implementation arrangements, cost and financing plan, and terms 
of references of the TA facility.3 
 
2.  Portfolio growth and challenges. ADB’s active portfolio in Nepal as of the end of 
December 2018 stands at $2.8 billion, with 31 loans amounting to $2.5 billion and 18 investment 
grants totaling $282.0 million. ADB’s annual lending commitment to Nepal averaged $253 million 
annually during 20142016, then increased to $510 million in 2017 and to $592 million in 2018. 
The forthcoming CPS envisages increasing this figure to about $600 million annually during 2020–
2024,  with  annual  contract  awards  and  disbursements  increasing  commensurately.  Nepal 
transitioned to a three-tiered federal system of governance in FY2018, with federal, provincial, 
and local governments entrusted to execute development projects. Increasingly, provincial and 
local  governments  will  implement  ADB-funded  projects.  But  ADB’s  experience  with  local 
governments suggests that they have limited capacity to meet ADB requirements. As provinces 
are  new  administrative  structures, capacity  strengthening  is  deemed  particularly  urgent for 
provincial governments with no prior experience of engaging with ADB.  
 
3.  Implementing the new federal structure and sustaining the performance of its active 
portfolio will be challenging for Nepal. Therefore, it is crucial to build the capacity of executing and 
implementing agencies of federal, provincial, and local governments. Insufficient capacity affects 
project performance in procurement, consultant recruitment, contract management, financial 
management, safeguards, gender equality and social inclusion (GESI), and project monitoring 
and evaluation. Furthermore, during implementation, projects frequently encounter problems 
surrounding  transfer  of  project  directors  and  other  key  project  staff,  so  regular  capacity 
development support is required. Hiring qualified contractors and consultants has been a problem; 
improving the performance of contractors and consultants will require effective procurement 
design, regular performance monitoring, and solid control mechanisms. Issues surrounding land 
                                                
1  ADB. 2013. Country Partnership Strategy: Nepal, 2013–2017. Manila. ADB extended the country partnership 
strategy, 2013–2017 until 2019. ADB. Forthcoming. Country Partnership Strategy: Nepal, 2020–2024. Manila; and 
ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2017. Country Operations Business Plan: Nepal, 2018–2020. Manila. The TA facility first appeared in the 
business opportunities section of ADB website on 28 August 2018.  
3  ADB received the confirmation on 1 July 2019.

2   
acquisition,  resettlement,  forest  clearance,  and  ensuring  right-of-way  also  hamper  project 
implementation. Resolving these issues will require improved interministerial coordination.  
 
4.  Continued  engagement.  ADB  has  been  addressing  these  challenges  through  the 
Capacity  Development  Resource  Center  (CDRC),  which  was  established  in  the  Nepal 
Administrative  Staff  College  (NASC)  through  ADB  TA  to  Nepal  for  Enhancing  Portfolio 
Performance.4 From December 2015 to May 2019, the CDRC delivered 54 training programs to 
more than 1,500 executing and implementing agencies staff working on ADB projects; these 
covered topics such as environmental and social safeguards, GESI, procurement, consultant 
recruitment,  contract  management,  financial  and  project  management,  and  preparation  of 
quarterly  project  progress  report.  The  CDRC  conducted  four  procurement  and  contract 
management clinics. NASC and ADB identified the training topics through a training needs 
assessment. NASC and ADB delivered the training programs, ensuring they were locally relevant, 
resource-driven, and economical. The TA (footnote 4) also supported the establishment of 
TPRMs as an institutional mechanism to address project implementation issues and support the 
successful completion and evaluation of projects. 
 
5.  The  TA  facility  will  support  the  continuation  of  demand-led  capacity  development 
programs, improve the quality of these programs, and continue to support the CDRC as a key 
mechanism  for  delivering  capacity  development  programs.  One  lesson  learned  from  the 
Enhancing  Portfolio  Performance  TA  was  that  identifying  training  needs  for  specific  target 
groups—for  instance,  new  implementing  agencies  or  senior  officers—yields  better  results. 
Therefore, the TA facility team will (i) conduct regular training needs assessments to identify 
specific capacity gaps of selected agencies, (ii) upgrade training materials through feedback 
received from participants, and (iii) combine field-based training programs and clinic-style issue-
resolution workshops with classroom training programs. The CDRC will closely coordinate and, 
where  feasible,  collaborate  with  ongoing  capacity  development  activities  supported  by  the 
government and/or other development partners.5 The CDRC will help establish pools of local 
trainers or resource persons in partnership with existing training institutes to institutionalize 
capacity building. In addition, the TA facility will provide project implementation support on 
environmental and safeguard compliance, contract management, financial management, and 
project management to critical ADB projects. ADB’s Disaster Resilience of Schools Project will be 
supported with capacity development in quality assurance of school designs, environmental and 
social safeguards compliance management, and financial management.6 The TA facility will 
                                                
4  ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance to Nepal for Enhancing Portfolio Performance. Manila. The TA is due for closure 
in September 2019. 
5  For instance, the Integrated Public Financial Management Reform Project implemented under a trust fund managed 
by the World Bank, which focuses on capacity development (specifically targeting procurement and financial 
management) of the Financial Comptroller General Office, Office of the Auditor General, Public Procurement 
Monitoring Office, and key central and subnational government agencies. Another large project is the Provincial and 
Local  Governance  Strengthening  Project  which  is  designed  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  the  sub-national 
governments to deliver public services. The project, which aims to start activities in 2020, is financed by the United 
Kingdom Department for International Development, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation, Norway, 
the European Union and United Nations Development Program, together with the Government of Nepal and includes,  
the development and strengthening of training centers in each provincial capital. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and 
General Administration will implement this project. In addition, the National Planning Commission has, as part of its 
mandate to support planning activities in the three-tiered federal system, prepared guidelines on planning, budgeting, 
and financial management for the subnational level, which can be a resource for capacity development activities. 
6  ADB. 2018. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan, Grant, and 
Administration of Grant to Nepal for Disaster Resilience of Schools Project. Manila. Implementation of this project 
commenced in early 2019. ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance to Nepal for Support for Project Implementation of the

3 
among others support the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Roads Improvement 
Project, the Melamchi Water Supply Project, and the Bagmati River Basin Improvement Project 
in environmental and social safeguards compliance and contract management.7 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
6.  Output 1: Capacity development of executing and implementing agencies increased. 
The TA facility will support the CDRC to conduct at least 50 capacity building programs to train 
about 1,500 staff from the executing and implementing agencies of ongoing and pipeline projects 
and associated federal, provincial, and local government staff during 20192023 and to conduct 
four clinics on procurement, social safeguards, financial management, and contract management 
targeted at individual projects. These capacity building programs will cover ADB policies and 
procedures,  project  implementation,  and  thematic  topics  for  improved  project  portfolio 
performance, with an emphasis on field-level, clinic-style, issue-resolution workshops, including 
the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the Procurement 
Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). The TA facility will support 
the CDRC to develop training programs based on capacity assessments of executing and 
implementing agencies and periodic training-needs surveys. The topics covered will include 
procurement, consultant  selection,  contract management,  project  management,  safeguards, 
GESI, financial management, and topics assessed from the periodic surveys. ADB staff from 
relevant ADB departments will be consulted to develop training material and where appropriate 
engaged as resource persons in the capacity building programs to discuss international best 
practices. The TA facility will further enhance the online training nomination and registration 
system to improve efficiency on training administration through web-based nominations, selection 
of  participants,  trainee  database,  trainee  tracking,  and  training  logistics  management. 
Development of e-learning modules for the capacity development activities implemented by 
CDRC, will also be supported. As part of the capacity development activities, the TA facility will 
support four business opportunity seminars to disseminate business opportunities to contractors 
and consultant organizations in collaboration with the World Bank and/or other development 
partners. The CDRC will conduct an impact assessment of training programs and improvements 
in monitoring and evaluation of portfolio results; this assessment will be used to improve the 
quality of capacity development. 
 
7.  Output 2: Cross-learning in between projects supported. The TA facility will support 
cross-learning between best practices in projects in Nepal as well as cross-learning learning from 
selected,  relevant  international  best  practices.  The  following  sub-outputs  are  proposed:  (i) 
representatives from executing and/or implementing agencies will be invited for at least five field 
visits  to  project  sites  from  successful  projects  for  hands-on  experience  on  good  project 
management practices; (ii) lessons learned from at least three ADB projects will be documented 
to  facilitate  improved  project  implementation  and  evaluation;  and  (iii)  representatives  from 
                                                
Nepal Earthquake Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Program. Manila. The TA which will close in December 2019, 
is providing support for quality assurance of school designs.  
7  ADB. 2016. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Nepal for the 
South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Roads Improvement Project. Manila. This project has special 
features on environmental safeguards management, especially focused on wildlife preservation. ADB. 2000. Report 
and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Nepal for the Melamchi Water 
Supply Project. Manila. ADB approved the additional financing for this project in 2014. ADB. 2013. Report and 
Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Grant, and Administration of the 
Technical Assistance Grant to Nepal for Bagmati River Basin Improvement Project. Manila. Approval of additional 
financing for this project is expected in 2019. These projects face social issues (among others) that impact 
contract management.

4   
executing  and/or  implementing  agencies  will  learn  through  an  estimated  five  international 
exposure visits about innovative technologies and capacity building initiatives relevant for Nepal. 
The TA facility will develop cross-learning activities for the education sector on innovations in 
school safety and the learning environment; for the energy sector and urban development on 
livable cities through trenchless technologies, horizontal direction drilling and tunneling, and 
rehabilitation of old sewer conduits; and for the agriculture sector on value chain improvement.8 
The TA team will identify additional areas for cross-learning activities during implementation.9 
 
8.  Output 3: Portfolio management improved. Improving the performance of ADB funded 
projects in Nepal  will include (i) funding ten TPRMs of ongoing and pipeline projects to support 
the quality and timeliness of implementation, including on-site performance reviews of specific 
projects by the MOF; (ii) supporting the ongoing Disaster Resilience of Schools Project (footnote 
6) by providing consultancy support for quality assurance on school designs to improve school 
safety and learning environments; and (iii) engaging individual consultants to provide capacity 
development support in procurement, contract management, financial management, reporting, 
safeguards, gender, and other areas for ongoing and pipeline critical projects (footnote 7 lists 
examples).10  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $1,650,00, of which $1,500,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, counterpart staff, facilities for seminars 
and meetings, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are 
in Appendix 1.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
10.  The International Economic Cooperation and Coordination Division of the MOF will be the 
executing agency responsible for providing the strategic direction for the implementation of the 
TA  facility.  ADB’s  Nepal  Resident  Mission  will  administer  the  TA  and  oversee  TA  facility 
implementation, working closely with TA beneficiaries to ensure the effective use of TA facility 
resources. The travel cost of ADB and non-ADB resource persons will be met from the proposed 
TA.  
 
11.  The TA team, through the TA facility, will provide workshops, conferences, and training 
programs through the national training institute. The national training institute proposed to be 
engaged to operate the CDRC, will host the online training nomination and registration system. 
 
12.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.  
 
                                                
8  The cross-learning on safe schools will benefit the Disaster Resilience of Schools Project (footnote 6). The cross-
learning on livable cities will benefit the Nepal Energy Authority and the Alternative Energy Promotion Centre, which 
implement energy projects; and the Ministry of Water Supply, the Ministry of Urban Development, and selected 
municipalities that implement urban projects. The cross-learning on value chain development will benefit the Ministry 
of Agriculture and selected provincial and local governments. 
9  ADB staff from relevant departments staff will be consulted and or engaged as resource persons for implementing 
cross-learning activities. 
10  ADB will update, as needed, the design and monitoring frameworks of ongoing projects to reflect the outputs and 
activities of the TA facility. The updated versions of these frameworks will be included in the project administration 
manuals of the supported projects.

5

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
13.  Consulting services. ADB will recruit eight individual national consultants for 111 person-
months and two individual international consultant for 12.5 person-months. 11 ADB will engage 
the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and 
its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.12 Furthermore, seven 
national consultants for 53 person-months will be recruited through a firm (NASC), which is 
subject to ADB’s approval. Appendix 2 has details on the allocation of consultants to the projects 
supported by the TA facility. 
 
14.  Given the diverse nature of the deliverables and the specialized expertise required, ADB 
will recruit some of the experts based on the individual consultant selection method. It is expected 
that NASC will deliver the capacity development training activities. NASC is an autonomous 
training entity designated by the government to develop and conduct training programs for 
government staff. NASC employs well-experienced trainers in the area of procurement, financial 
management, social safeguards, and GESI; has faculties with dedicated training units that are 
able to administer training events, including preparation of training materials in local languages; 
and owns a campus with an adequate number of training halls and a hostel for residential training 
with a 24-hour electricity supply. NASC has been providing similar services for ADB since 2015 
under the Enhancing Portfolio Performance TA project, and no other national firms are able to 
provide these services. Therefore, it is proposed that NASC be selected to provide training 
through  direct  contracting,  per  para.  86(ii)  of  the  Staff  Instructions  on  ADB-administered 
consulting  services,  which  indicates  that  direct  contracting  can  be  applied  when  only  one 
consultant is qualified or has experience of exceptional worth of the relevant assignment.13 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Nepal for Portfolio Management and Capacity Development for Enhanced 
Portfolio Performance, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
                                                
11 As appropriate, ADB will consider output-based (lump sum) contracts.  
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
13 ADB. 2016. Delegation of Approval Authority under Financing Partnership Operations. Compendium of Staff 
 
Instructions. Manila.
